titlestmt.author: Fantasia Thorne and Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 4, 2019 at 22:00

did.abstract: Correspondence, sermons, lectures, writings, reports, slides, and collected material document the life and work of David M. Stowe, who was a top level executive for the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, the United Church Board for World Ministries, and the National Council of Church Division of Overseas Ministries. The collection includes extensive documentation of the history of the ABCFM and UCBWM that Stowe compiled in preparation for writing a history of the Boards.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: David M. Stowe Papers (RG 156), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

list.item: Series II. Sermons, Lectures, Talks by DMS, 1942-1999
Series IV. Drafts, Notes,Sources for Proposed Board History, 1812-1980s
Series V. Resource Files: ABCFM/UCBWM Documents, 1806-1996
Series VI. Resource Files: ABCFM/UCBWM Geographical / Topical Files, 1810-2003
Series VIII. DMS Activities: Church and Ecumenical, 1954-1999
Series IX: DMS Activities: Teaching and Research, 1949-1990s
Series X. Personal Items and Memorabilia, 1911-2000

chronitem.event: David Metz Stowe was born in Council Bluffs, Iowa

After attending Midland Lutheran College for two years, DMS transferred to the from University of California at Los Angeles and graduated with highest honors. Phi Beta Kappa 1943 B.D., Pacific School of Religion, Berkeley, CA
Married Virginia Ware (Children: Nancy, Elizabeth, Priscilla, David)
Ordained; served as campus minister at First Congregational Church, a United Church congregation in Berkeley
Under appointment as missionaries of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, DMS and VWS studied Chinese language and culture at Yale University Institute of Far Eastern Languages
Left for China; additional study at Chinese Language School in Peking
Assigned to general evangelistic work in Tientsin
Assigned to faculty of Yenching University in Peking. DMS and VWS taught freshman English and DMS taught Western philosophy and New Testament in the School of Religion
Forced to leave China because of outbreak of Korean War
Served as Associate Minister of the First Congregational Church in Berkeley while attending Pacific Sschool of Religion
Received Th.D. degree from Pacific School of Religion
Served as Chaplain and professor of religion at Carleton College, Northfield, MN
Called to the national headquarters of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (ABCFM) in Boston to serve as its educational secretary

General Secretary for Interpretation and Personnel of the newly formed United Church Board for World Ministries (UCBWM) following merger of Congregational Christian Churches and Evangelical and Reformed Church to form the United Church of Christ (UCC); also served as adjunct professor at Andover-Newton Theological School during this period
On special assignment in Beirut, Lebanon, to teach in the Near East School of Theology. Also visited missions and participated in conferences in Asia, Africa and the Middle East
Returned to U.S. to serve as Executive Secretary of the Division of Foreign Missions of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. (NCCCUSA)
Associate General Secretary of the NCCCUSA and director of the Division of Overseas Ministries
Honorary doctorate from Pacific School of Religion
Served as Executive Vice President of the United Church Board for World Ministries

In the years following his retirement from the UCBWM, DMS served as volunteer archivist and historian for the UCBWM, adjunct lecturer in missions at Andover Newton, Theological Seminary, adjunct professor at Pacific School of Religion (1985-1986), secretary-treasurer of the Eastern Fellowship,American Society of Missiology, officer of the World Commission on Religion and Peace, and tour leader for UCC tours to China.
Died in Englewood, NJ

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of David M. Stowe are valuable both for their biographical documentation and for the extensive documentation they contain related to the history of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions and United Church Board for World Ministries. Throughout his long career as a China missionary, professor, and mission executive, David Stowe was an acute observer and wise analyst of the many issues facing the Christian enterprise in the second half of the twentieth century. Stowe was both a theologian and an historian. His extensive writings theological and missions-related issues and his participation in many important meetings and events are well documented in this collection. A large portion of the collection consists of the material Stowe wrote and gathered in preparation for writing a comprehensive history of the ABCFM and UCBWM. Stowe never completed this work but has left behind a well-organized and extensive gathering of source materials that will be of use to researchers on many topics.

controlaccess.subject: Missions -- China
Missionaries
controlaccess.corpname: American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions
United Church Board for World Ministries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of primarily personal correspondence. The family letters and circular letters begin with documentation of the Stowes' work as missionaries in China and provide a good overview of their activities in various locations and positions. Correspondence from the later years documents Stowe's wide circle of friends and colleagues and his work in providing and gathering information about the ABCFM and UCBWM. A set of microfilm containing Stowe's correspondence as Executive Vice President of the UCBWM, 1970-1985, completes the series. See additional correspondence in Series XI, Addendum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The extent and variety of speaking engagements by Stowe documented in this series provide good documentation of his personal beliefs and views on mission policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Stowe's extensive writings on historical, missions-related, and theological topics. In his later years, he wrote many entries for reference works on ABCFM missions and missionaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Following his retirement in 1985, Stowe was deeply engaged in gathering material for and beginning to write a comprehensive history of the ABCFM and UCBWM. This series contains his outlines and some drafts of chapters for the work, which was never completed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains resources that Stowe compiled to assist him in writing his proposed history of the ABCFM and UCBWM. A comprehensive set of printed missionary circular letters provides a valuable overview of ABCFM/UCBWM mission activity, especially from the 1940s to the 1980s. Reports and documentation from the many Board meetings that Stowe attended also provide a good overview of issues and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports, brochures, pamphlets, writings, photographs and ephemera related to ABCFM/UCBWM missionaries, schools, hospitals and other mission activities. Many of the items are published on the mission field and provide valuable on-the-ground documentation. David and Virginia Stowe developed these resources as a sort of "vertical file" in the UCBWM New York office. Materials that were official archives or publications of the UCBWM have been sent to their archives in Cleveland. The documentation is particularly strong in the area of China because the Stowes served as missionaries there from 1947-1950 and developed many life-long relationships with missionary colleagues. These colleagues often sent Stowe materials related to their work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series represents the extensive alphabetical filing system kept by Stowe to organize collected materials and notes on a variety of topics and issues. It gives a good sense of the wide range of his interests and involvements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Stowe's involvement with church and ecumenical organizations. Official correspondence and documents related to the ABCFM/UCBWM would be in the UCBWM archives in Cleveland. The "Meetings and Conferences" sub-series documents Stowe's participation in many of the most important mission-related and ecumenical gatherings of the second half of the 20th century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addition to his executive administration positions with organizations, Stowe also taught and engaged in research projects throughout his career. This series documents courses he taught and his strong interest in Process Theology and Interreligious Dialogue. The final sub-series contains valuable biographical documentation about ABCFM missionaries to 1957, compiled for a proposed project to update the "Vinton" books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The "Vinton Books" are a series of compiled biographical information about missionaries who served under the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. DMS was working on a project to update the Vinton volumes, using information from Board personnel files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes biographical information about Stowe, slides that he took on his various travels, and a number of interesting collected artifacts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material includes working papers, minutes, and reports of annual meetings of the Theological Education Fund from the years when Stowe served as United Board for World Ministries (UCC)representative to the Fund. From 1958 to 1977 the Theological Education Fund focused on strengthening and renewing theological education in developing countries. In 1977 it was superseded by the Programme on Theological Education, a sub-unit of the World Council of Churches.

did.unittitle: Directory of Theological School and related institutions in Africa, Asia, the Caribbean, Latin America & South Pacific - published by Theological Education Fund
A Theological Book List - published by Theological Education Fund
